title: The Story of McDonalds
text:
Hey there, data explorer! Let’s embark on a journey through the golden arches and dive into the fascinating world of McDonald’s. Buckle up, because we’re about to unravel some intriguing insights!
Here, we have a map of all the McDonalds around the world!

title: The Story of McDonalds
text: The Big Mac Price

title: The Story of McDonalds
section: McDonald’s All Around the World (As of 2022)
text:
McDonald’s All Around the World (As of 2022)



McDonald’s Density Hot Spots
With the ‘McDonald’s Outlets per Million Residents’ toggle activated, a clear trend emerges – the density of McDonald’s locations is notably high in the US, Canada, Europe, and Australia. This concentration indicates a strong presence in these regions relative to their populations. However, the story takes an interesting turn when we examine countries with the least dense McDonald’s to Population ratio, such as Peru, Egypt, and India.


The Golden Arches and GDP
When toggling on ‘GDP per Capita’, you may notice that there is barely any changes in colour, save a few countries like China and some regions in Europe etc. The graph shows that there is a positive correlation between GDP per capita and the number of McDonald’s outlets in a country. This is consistent with the findings from the first graph, which showed that wealthier countries tend to have more McDonald’s outlets per million residents.
This correlation can be explained by a number of factors, including:

Wealthier countries tend to have more urbanization and higher levels of disposable income. This creates a larger market for fast food restaurants like McDonald’s.
Wealthier countries also tend to have more foreign direct investment. McDonald’s is one of the world’s largest foreign direct investors, and it has a long history of expanding into new markets.
Some people argue that McDonald’s is a symbol of Western culture and globalization. Wealthier countries are more likely to be exposed to Western culture and globalization, and this may lead to a greater demand for McDonald’s restaurants.



Exploring Disparities
The countries with lower McDonald’s density often share common characteristics. Many are classified as developing nations, where disposable income is limited, and supply chains pose considerable challenges. Additionally, some countries attribute their low McDonald’s density to political reasons, a small local population, or simply a lack of affinity for American fast-food burgers.


Africa: A Unique Landscape
Zooming in on Africa, a continent seemingly devoid of McDonald’s presence, we uncover a myriad of factors influencing this phenomenon.







Factors
Implications




Economic Challenges
Africa’s diverse economic landscape poses challenges like poverty, political instability, and underdeveloped infrastructure. These hurdles can hinder McDonald’s efforts to establish profitable operations in certain regions.


Cultural Diversity
Africa’s rich culinary heritage presents a complex challenge. While McDonald’s adapts menus to local tastes, achieving a balance between global consistency and diverse local preferences becomes intricate in a continent with such culinary variety.


Supply Chain Struggles
McDonald’s stringent quality standards rely on efficient supply chains. Inadequate infrastructure, including transportation and logistics, in Africa can impede the reliable supply of ingredients, affecting the company’s quality standards.


Fierce Competition
The fast-food industry in Africa is fiercely competitive, with local and international chains vying for market share. Entering this market demands careful research and an effective competitive strategy.


Regulatory Complexities
Different African countries have varying regulations for foreign businesses. Navigating these diverse regulatory frameworks can be time-consuming and financially burdensome for McDonald’s.

title: McDonald’s :^)
text:
setwd("//Users/kyrawu/kyraxwu.github.io/McDonalds/DataSet/APAC mcd menus")
df = read_csv("[2023-11-03 07_37_15] mcd-api-in.csv")

Rows: 219 Columns: 8
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (4): Day, Territory, Menu Item, Category
dbl  (3): ...1, Price (INR), Price (USD)
date (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

df = df %>% mutate(`Price (USD)` = round(`Price (INR)`*0.0120268, 2) ) #fixing calculation error in data
write_csv(df, "[2023-11-03 07_37_15] mcd-api-in.csv")

##apac_menus

setwd("/Users/kyrawu/kyraxwu.github.io/McDonalds/DataSet")
bmi = read_csv("BigmacPrice.csv")

Rows: 1946 Columns: 6
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (2): currency_code, name
dbl  (3): local_price, dollar_ex, dollar_price
date (1): date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

outlets = read_csv("most mcdonalds countries 2022 - Sheet1.csv")

Rows: 101 Columns: 4
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): Country, First Opening
dbl (1): Number of Restaurants per Million Population
num (1): Number of Restaurants

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

nutrition = read_xlsx("pffy-data-mcdonalds-nutrition-facts.xlsx", sheet = 1)
setwd("/Users/kyrawu/kyraxwu.github.io/McDonalds/DataSet/APAC mcd menus")
csv_files=list.files(pattern = "*.csv$")
apac_menus = NULL

for (file in csv_files) {
  df <- read.csv(file, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
  required_columns <- c("Territory", "Menu.Item", "Price..USD.", "Category")
  # Check if the "Menu" column exists, if not, create it with NA values
  if(!("Menu" %in% names(df))) {
    df$Menu <- NA  # Add the Menu column with NA values
  }
  df <- df[, c(required_columns, "Menu"), drop = FALSE]
  # Bind this dataframe to the merged dataframe
  if (is.null(apac_menus)) {
    apac_menus <- df
  } else {
    apac_menus <- rbind(apac_menus, df)
  }
}
setwd("/Users/kyrawu/kyraxwu.github.io/McDonalds/DataSet")
names(apac_menus) = c("territory", "menu item", "price", "category", "menu")
write_csv(apac_menus, "apac_menus.csv")

##outlets data

#install.packages("countrycode")
#install.packages("maps")
library(countrycode)
library(maps)


Attaching package: 'maps'


The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    map

# Add country code
outlets <- outlets %>%
  mutate(country_code = countrycode(Country, "country.name", "iso3c"),
         outlets_per_mil = `Number of Restaurants per Million Population`,
         num_outlets = `Number of Restaurants`) %>%
  select(-`Number of Restaurants per Million Population`, -`Number of Restaurants`)

# Create a lookup table for latitudes and longitudes
world_cities <- maps::world.cities %>%
  distinct(country.etc, lat, long) %>%
  rename(Country = country.etc)
world_cities <- world_cities %>%
  mutate(Country = case_when(
    Country == "Bahamas" ~ "The Bahamas",
    Country == "Korea South" ~ "South Korea",
    TRUE ~ Country
  ))

outlets <- left_join(outlets, world_cities, by = "Country")
centroids <- outlets %>%
  group_by(Country) %>%
  summarize(
    centroid_lat = mean(lat, na.rm = TRUE),
    centroid_long = mean(long, na.rm = TRUE)
  )
outlets <- left_join(outlets, centroids, by = "Country") %>% select(-"lat", -"long") %>% distinct()

outlets <- outlets  %>%
    mutate(Country = tolower(Country)) # Ensure country names are in lowercase for matching
world_countries <- ne_countries(scale = "medium", returnclass = "sf")

# Join with your data
outlets <- world_countries %>%
    left_join(outlets, by = c("adm0_a3" = "country_code")) %>% 
    select("name","outlets_per_mil", "num_outlets", "First Opening", "pop_est", "gdp_md_est", "economy", "income_grp", "geometry", "centroid_lat","centroid_long") %>% na.omit()

outlets_wkt <- outlets
outlets_wkt$geometry <- st_as_text(outlets$geometry)


# Write updated dataset
write_csv(outlets_wkt, "outlets.csv")
